What's the "first article" in this case? The one I saw here was from dorkly, and AFAIK it just reprinted the Cartoon Brew comments.

The article clearly says they spoke to some of the animators, and Variety have been around long enough and have built up enough goodwill and credibility for that to be plausible coming from them, as opposed to sites that just reported on the comments coming from the Cartoon Brew article. How are they a blog?

WRITING.TITLE: Arthur Hiller Dead: Love Story Director Was 92

WRITING.TEXT: Variety isn't a blog, it's one of the oldest entertainment magazines out there. They wouldn't publish something without verifying it first. Most other sources simply went off of comments on the cartoon brew article, while Variety stated they spoke to some animators about it.

I'm just worried they won't have someone like Jake Sinclair or Ric Ocasek holding down the fort. Rivers has said in interviews that Sinclair pushed for a more classic sound on White, and Rivers wasn't a very big fan of that. But hey, I quite liked I Love the USA, so...

He's a good bassist, but Green wasn't a good use of his talents. Practically all of his basslines are turned way down in the mix and simply follow the guitars, so it's hard to tell what he's doing. You can isolate some of them with the help of Rock Band stems, and it's clear that he's a solid player. It's a shame he never really got to spread his wings in the band musically, and the scenarios surrounding his departure bum me out. Scott is a talented guy, although for a while dull production and mix burials made it hard to assess his talent. Thankfully he was with the band long enough to get to do interesting things on bass.

What's Scott even up to these days?
I have no idea how you would even go about getting an AMA with him.

The Rentals are a good answer to OP's question, actually. Return of the Rentals is a breezy pop record with earworms galore, but it's followed up by the crushingly bloated Seven More Minutes, which reeked of the band trying too hard to prove they could do more beyond little Moog jams. Lost in Alphaville is essentially their first album but more soulless (although Irrational Things is pretty solid)

Worst Weezer album by far, imo. The production is both boring and awful (the clipping on *Ruling Me* - how was that not caught and fixed?) which is probably the biggest issue - for me, almost every song is impossible to listen to with all the weird shit going on. I guess it's to mask how Rivers' vocals sound so dogged and that the rest of the band aren't bringing much in the way of passionate playing either. Even if the album actually sounded fine, practically none of the songs have interesting or salvageable loglines. Where's My Sex and Smart Girls are two of the most embarrassing tunes to ever be put on a record anywhere, not just Weezer. You know an album rots when there's a bonus track written by the composer of Yo Gabba Gabba for a kids' show and it's still better than almost each tune on the regular release.
(Unspoken is pretty awesome, though.)
Can you really do it without Charles Napier? He was one of the best parts of the original series. Also Christine Cavanaugh
